title: Employment;job characteristics, cao
maintainer_displayname: ZBO | Centraal Bureau voor de Statistiek
name: employmentjob-characteristics-cao
notes:
This table comprises yearly figures on the main aspects of employment, wages and working hours in the Netherlands. The information in this table is classified according to Standard Industrial Classification of all Economic Activities (SIC 2008) and can be broken down into:
- employee characteristics (age and sex)
- job characteristics (type of employment contract, working hours company car: yes or no, and overtime: yes or no)
- company characteristics (size of the firm and collective wage agreements)

Data available from: 2009.

Status of the figures:
The figures in this table are definite.

Changes as of 20 February 2015:
The new figures for 2013 are added except the figures of the subjects 'Car of the company' and 'Overtime' under selection 'Job characterics'.

Changes as of 7 April 2014:
The SIC Classification of the CAO sector has been changed for the year 2009. For 2009 it had been based on SIC93. As of 2010 the allocation of jobs to the SIC sector is based on the SIC 2008 classification. The new allocation for 2009 has led to an increase of 6 thousand jobs in the private sector. These jobs originate from the subsidised institutions (-4 thousand jobs) and the government (-2 thousand jobs). 
In the figures from 2010 onwards (after the change of method), Statistics Netherlands made a change for the number of jobs and the labour volume with ‘0’ as their value. The figures of  ‘payment per job’ and ‘working hours’ were also set to ‘0’. These cells included too little data. In the past these cells had been filled. 
There has been a correction of 7 thousand jobs on the total level of revision year 2010 (after the change of methods).  Double records were accidently used when previous outcomes of Statline were compiled.

When will new figures be published?
The figures of 'Car of the company' and 'Overtime' for the year 2013 will be published in the fourth quarter of 2015.
New figures for 2014 will be published in the fourth quarter of 2015.
